channel.title: Should these monitors provide amplification?
channel.description:
I've got a pair of these monitors: http://www.behringer.com/EN/Products/B2031A.aspx (Behringer TRUTH B2031A)
I know absolutely nothing about audio engineering so don't know if these monitors (or any studio monitors) are supposed to provide amplification. Like if you buy an all-in-one speaker set (like Bose or something) it amplifies the tiny headphone jack signal. The website does say they are amplified, but there's no volume knob so I don't really understand how this works.. will they just amplify to the max and I'm supposed to turn the computer volume down?
The reason I can't just test them is because the circuits are apparently damaged (they're not mine, and quite old), so I don't know if the quiet sound I'm getting is due to lack of amplification or just because they're broken.
tldr; I want to connect these to my computer, should they amplify for me??

item.title: Should these monitors provide amplification?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Ignore the guy above, yes these monitors do contain their own amplifier - that’s what the A in the name refers to, they are active monitors rather than passive.

There may be a volume control on the back with the shelf controls etc., if not you’re probably expected to control it from your mixer.

EDIT: There is indeed a control on the back - it’s labelled ‘Input Trim’.

Read full topic

item.title: Should these monitors provide amplification?
item.dc:creator: @Christmas_tree Christmas_tree
item.description:
@Christmas_tree wrote:

They are just speakers. All it is is a speaker cone in a box. There is nothing to power them. You need a power source to work them.

Same with guitar cabinets. Guitar cabinets don’t work standalone - they need a head (or other source) to power them.
